description: Stopped here for dinner while doing a "tourist" day on a recent visit to SFO. The views of the water are beautiful and I think that was the best part. Food was average but with above average (even for a tourist area) pricing. Service was fine and no problems there. If you want a kitchy thing to do and see a bit of San Fran dining history, this is worth a look, but if it's just good food you are looking for at these prices I would move this down the list.
author: Peter Q.

description: This place deserves five stars for the view!  My co-worker and I ate here right after a weekend-long work event, and the hostess sat us at a table with the perfect view of the sunset--it was SO GORGEOUS!  Service is great.  Perfect place for corny little tourists like me and my co-worker!  ...but food was just average.  Got a special that included an appetizer, dinner, and dessert.  All were just ok.  BUT, again, the view and the interior were fabulous and fun and made great memories.  I would definitely return...but just order something else :)
author: Cat H.

description:
The mussels are delicious. Cooked in Garlic Butter and sprinkled with sea salt. For the side, there is a delicious butter garlic pesto.

I also had the crab enchilada which is delicious.

I tasted my friends crab melt and halibut. The crab melt was pressed between soft sourdough bread - easy to eat. ( great inspiration for a lunch or snack ). The halibut had a lemon zest taste, also easy to eat.

P.S The new menu is interesting, I would appreciate more recipes.
author: Fatimah A.

description:
Never, ever, eat at a sit-down restaurant that has photographs of the food on the menu.

I've learned to apply this lesson while dining in other countries -- you'd think I would apply it while dining in my own country.

My husband and I stopped here to grab dinner after a nice afternoon of strolling through the city and enjoying the sights. The restaurant has a wonderful view of the bay but don't let it tempt you! The food is mediocre and the restaurant is dirty. This place is a tourist trap that is focused on table turnover and doesn't pay much attention to the details. 

Go here if you're hungry and just want to get in and out. Don't go here if you are in to great food and great dining.
author: Vanessa B.

description: I came here for my birthday and I was treated really well.They looked out for me and give me extra stuff,there was this one waiter who was really kool,he bought me and my cousin a glass of champagne and they stopped us as we were leaving and we drank it at the little var they have,and not only that we got to recipe books in a gift bag:)That was really sweet and it wasnt just him all the waiters were very attentive but i can understand why this restaurant does not have 5 stars,the food was a little overpriced and they didnt give you much,but I think you pay for me the looks and the beauty of the restaruant it had really great veiws and was very pretty I will be going back again,if your ever in san fransisco you should defintly stop here and see it for yourself:)
author: Theresa C.

description:
This place can get a bit pricey, but they have a PREFIXE MENU!!

We had clam chowder, halibut in thai curry sauce with clams/mussels, and kustard for $30.

There is a lot of options on this menu and different price ranges for the 3 course meals. 

Great view of the island also helps.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Do YOU love restaurants that have FREE parking, an EXQUISITE view of the bay, a deliciously extensive menu, and now offer a $19.99 prix fixe menu? If so, then this is the place for you.

I stumbled across this restaurant with my parents about two years ago. It's an SF institution, and celebrated its 50th anniversary back in 2007. I think that if it's been around for that long, then it must be good.

Anyway, this is a place that I like to go to with my family for a nice dinner out, celebration, holiday, etc. Last night I made it over there with a "date," and it was fabulous!

You can make a reservation on opentable.com, and we were promptly seated in a booth in the middle of the restaurant. Due to the state of our economy, they now offer $19.99 and $29.99 prix fixe menus that are SO WORTH IT. 

For $19.99 I had: clam chowder,  tender braised short rib (served with mashed potatoes and broccolini), and vanilla ice cream for dessert. Yum. My date has the same, but with their spicy prawn pasta. We left totally satisfied with the food and service, and with doggy bags!
author: Misha F.

description: Wow! Gorgeous place, professional and immaculate service, and outstanding seafood / steak.
author: Stephen H.

description: I had better *u*king service at wendys fast food in compton.!
author: Nicholas W.

description:
We decided to have Christmas Dinner here. I haven't been here since I came with my parents back in the 60's. The place was remodeled in 2005. It is already showing signs of wear. The booths are covered in a red material and it is already wearing off at the ends from people getting in and out of the booths, the very fancy glass light fixture over our table was dirty and some of the lights were burned out. My sister always says  "A burned out light bulb is the sign of a burned out manager." 

All that being said, the view is great and the food was great. They have a really fantastic menu book with pictures and recipes. We started out with the Misto Sampler Appetizer. It was really good, especially the Burrata. We had a group of 6 and 4 shared the roasted crab feast. They all raved about it. I had the Seafood Cioppino, it was loaded with crab, clams, calamari and fish. Delicious. My wife had the Boneless Short Rib and was delighted. All of the deserts were elegant and delicious.

The location, right at Fisherman's Wharf, is terrific. Watch out for the "Free Parking" though. The sign says 3 hours free with validation but they charge you for anything over 2 hours. You have to argue with them to get the 3rd hour. They need to change the sign. The parking is independent and it is very annoying to have this happen. We had the same thing happen when we went to Tarrantino's back in April. The parking attendants have to deal with this all the time and they must be fed up with it because they are callous, rude and abrupt.
author: Al G.

description: Rock solid views of the GG Bridge and Alcatraz.  Fun pictures of celebrities scattered throughout the restaurant.  Large portions are good for sharing with several people.  I was there mid week during the day, but would guess the night time and/or weekends get quite busy.
author: Stacy L.

description: My wife and I ate at the Franciscan and we're impressed.  The view from all tables was fantastic,  our server was excellent, she was very nice and checked on us at all the right times. The food was very good and different. I'd never had crab enchiladas before but I liked them. And the restaurant was not too noisy so we could have  a normal level conversation.
author: Fred D.

description: "We always eat here when we visit San Francisco . It's a tourist appeal place. Great character and view. Food is ok too. If you are a tourist don't miss it."
author: Ken S.

description: Gorgeous and great for groups - We had a large group meeting for lunch and some of the party was running very behind. They were extremely accommodating and patient as our group trickled in due to unforeseen traffic during the boat races. The food was delicious and service was fantastic--not to forget the incredible view of the bay!!!
author: Elizabeth W.

description: We had an absolutely amazing time at the Franciscan! The food was delicious, perfectly timed, and perfectly cooked. Our server, Yuri, was one of the best, if not the best, servers we've ever had! He ensured we had the best experience possible. We'd recommend this restaurant to anyone because it provides a true San Fran experience as well as panoramic views of the Bay, Alcatraz, Bay Bridge, and Coit Tower. Thanks again, we will be back!
author: Sarah J.

description: The prosciutto was amazing! Great service, friendly bar atmosphere
author: Becky R.

description:
This year for Thanksgiving we decided to skip the traditional turkey dinner and head out to San Francisco for some crab.  I know that Fisherman's Wharf is touristy, but I absolutely love it out there.  
We made reservations at the Franciscan since we have seen it a thousand times, but have never been in to try the food.  The place is beautiful inside, I loved the decor and the large windows with views of the bay. 
The service was outstanding and the food was absolutely delicious!  I'd recommend the Dungeness Crab Cakes as an appetizer, Surf & Turf Crab with Petit Filet Mignon and the Crab Enchiladas.
author: Brandy A.

description: Went on a Friday night. Place was hoppin'. All our meals were great as were the drinks and beers. Wait staff was slow, but we had a great view so it didn't seem so bad.
author: Dan M.

description: My dining experience doesn't really rate a full 3 stars!  I ordered the Fish and Chips.The Fries were well seasoned and good. The Fish was nicely prepared. I had a cup of Clam Chowder as a starter but the potatoes were not fully cooked. The real tragedy was in my dining partner's order of Salmon. Although she said it was tasty the tiny portion was outrageous and certainly not worthy of its $27.95 price! The order normally came with mashed potatoes but she requested French Fries instead. That portion was also meager. Had it not been for my giving her some of my Fries she would have left hungry. However I appreciated the nice service.
author: Aleece C.

description: The Franciscan is consistently good.  Every table in the house has a great view. Give it a try and you will be pleased. Great seafood.
author: Live For Foo D.

description:
Today was a magnificent day in the Bay. San Francisco hasn't had a day where there were no clouds in the sky and the sun beaming down hotter than ever in quite a while. Because it was my day off I didn't want to waste anytime by spending the day lagging and lounging around the house. My boyfriend and I decided to drive down to the pier and enjoy this bright sunny day. We originally were going to eat at Joe's Crab Shack, but decided on eating here at the Franciscan. Somewhere we've never been before. I've walked the pier numerous times, but have never stopped to notice this restaurant.

We walked up to the front and entered the restaurant without hesitation. The hostess greeted us right away.  She quickly sat us at a booth infront of their tall wide windows. As soon as I glanced to my left I was in total awe with the amazing view. The sky was lit brighter than ever and in the distance I could see Alcatraz. We sat down at our table and the hostess handed us our menus.  The menus looked like a thick book. It must have been at least 1.5 inches thick. The menu was very detailed with pictures and had full descriptions of everything ranging from anti-pasta, appetizers, entrees, and desserts.

We each ordered a cup of chowder. He had the crab chowder and I had the clam chowder. I didn't order a bread bowl, because they had already served us complimentary bread and butter. For our main course we ordered the Double Mussels and Double Crab on a sizzling plate for two. Let me tell you, it was great! The dish was bursting with flavors. Both the mussels and the crab legs were still freshly hot. You could see the steam rising from the platter. I ate slow and basked all the flavors of the spices and sauce in my mouth. Instead of scarfing it all down in one fast sitting I took my time without rushing one bite.

As a first timer, I have to say that my first experience here at this restaurant was excellent! Our waiter was extremely friendly and did not rush us. After we finished our meal they cleaned our table and removed all the dirty plates. Our waiter asked if we would like to look over the dessert menu, but I kindly passed. He then responded "Okay, but if you'd like we have small dessert cups that we offer for free. Would you like two of them?" I told him we'd take one. Only because I know I wasn't going to finish all of mine if I got my own. I'm not big on sweets. So, the boyfriend and I shared one of their dessert cups in which they gave a generous amount of vanilla icecream. By the time we were finish I definitely was full and satisfied with what we had ordered.

I highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who is interested in eating at a brightly lit restaurant with superb customer service. The restaurant has a 50's feel with black and white pictures surrounding the walls. Plus, who doesn't like crab? You won't want to pass on this spectacular restaurant and their delicious food.
author: Cassie D.

description: Perfect for drinks and small plates unless you want to go for the full meal.  Prices are mostly fair, keeping in mind that you are dining in the Wharf. Blood orange margarita it's perfectly sour with your preference of tequila; in my case patron silver. Ask for the Cucumber Gin martini as I don't believe it's featured on the menu anymore, but certainly packs a refreshing punch. I started off with the prosciutto plate along with octopus crustini and yellowtail carpaccio which the latter being my absolute favorite. Nice hint of pronounced acidity served with table bread to absorb all the good oils and flavors. Service was friendly a little slow if you're expecting a timely meal. All in all a well favored 4 *'s.
author: John P.

description:
We ordered the lotsa crab, which was supposed to be three crabs.  However I don't know if we really received 3 crabs.  Didn't seem like it.  But the flavor was good, not as good as Mama's Garlic and Butter Crab of course.  But delicious.

I had the mini Fillet Mignon with their Yukon Mashed Potatoes.  OMG!!! You have to try it, meat was like Buttah and the mashed potatoes, yup to die for!

My boyfriend had the Spicy Shrimp Pasta, also delicious.  My sister had the Thai Curry Halibut, which smelled like curry but was missing the curry flavor. 

For dessert we had the Lemon Tart with Vanilla Frozen Kustard.  I don't generally like lemon but I loved this thing.  I'd go back just for dessert.  My sister and her boyfriend ordered just the Vanilla Frozen Kustard and it came out in a HUGE gauntlet, we had to help them eat it cause I don't think they would've finished it on their own LOL.

Oh, and be careful with ordering drinks they're not cheap.

All in all it was a delicious night.  Granted the bill came to $420 for 6 of us.  But we definitely recommend it!  Oh and I forgot to mention they have binoculars at the window seats so you can check out the view.  Not as useful at night of course LOL.
author: Nissa Z.

description: On a quick get-away trip, my wife and I were seated w/o a reservation at a nice seat by the window overlooking the bay. The waiter was extremely courteous and even accommodated an "off the menu" request. Had the oysters for starters, then moved on to the best Cioppino I've had! topped it off with their staple dish, the crab... excellent! My wife's favorite part was the asparagus broccoli side dish.. they flash fry it, so it has a slight crisp thing going on. Best restaurant on this trip so far!
author: Lowell G.

description: Have been here several times now, but finally writing my first review of this place. Would normally give it 5 stars, as the food rocks and the views are breathtaking. The loss of the star on this visit is for our waiter. I know it was later in the evening, and he may have been one of the only ones left working on a bunch of tables, but still, for the price we paid, you'd expect top notch service. Also, the fact that I made a reservation and still got stuck in a corner table near the bathrooms. Gotta love the crab here though, between here and crab house on pier 39, only places I go for SF Dungeness.
author: Travis A.

description:
Every time I'm in SF, I have a lunch at Franiscan Crab Restaurant. Sometimes it's overcrowded but food is always fresh and tasty. Once we've tried out seafood delicacies such as crabs, mussels and schrimps and it was so good! Clam chowder is my favorite dish. The tastiest soup I've ever had!
Service is nice, but could be better.
The thing I love about this place is an amazing view of the bay that you can see from every table in the restaurant. This place won't let you down.
author: Alina A.

description: I ate here years ago, so when we ended up at the Wharf last week, I figured: "why not? These tourist traps are all the same." I don't remember what I ate then, but I can tell you with absolute certainty that everything we had last week was a winner. The service was spot on and my glass was never empty. Me, a glass of wine, the 2nd best burrata ever (no lie - it was excellent) delish crab, dangerously good bread and a view of Alcatraz? Happy Lauren!
author: Lauren H.

description:
Great place for drinks next to a view of the bay. Very standard mediocre seafood restaurant in Fisherman's wharf area. Its in a touristy area, but once you're in the restaurant its not crowded and doesn't have the cheesy touristy vibe at all.

Service was great food was good too. Definitely try the crab fondue and the crab cocktail. Their bloody marys are also delicious as well.
author: S. V.

description:
Had lunch here and enjoyed the food, but especially loved the view.  I would go here again just to sit at their diner like booths that face the window.  It was very calming and the crab chowder was yummy.  Just got a cup, but would probably recommend getting it in the bread bowl.  

Had the house salad with their special blue cheese dressing.  The dressing was to die for.
author: Jessica Y.

description: Came here with out of town guests and 5 of us shared the 4 person crab feast. Definitely glad we stopped in, wife and I have done the crab thing at 2 other sit down Wharf restaurants and this was our favorite so far. The yellowtail carpaccio was quite delicious as well. Great view of course with a lot of good decorum. Also, the 4 person crab feast was just right for the 5 of us, and we're all pretty good eaters.
author: E M.

description:
Great table, great service, 

BAD FOOD!! 
EXPENSIVE!!

oh wait, their chowder wasn't that bad.. if you like progressive clam chowder hahahhahaha 

Not recommended.. I am from seattle and we get the best of the best, and I have been quite disappointed at franciscan ... mostly when people were recommending this place left and right... if I wanted red lobster I'd go to red lobster... FIN
author: Nina M.

description: I generally stay away from the area - Fisherman's Wharf is for tourists. But, when friends wanted to go, I did - and, to my surprise, the prices were reasonable and the food was good. 3 course pre-fixe dinners for $24.95! I'd go back.
author: Peter S.

description: I personally Loved this restaurant. I chose it randomly and my friend took me there for my birthday. Nice atmosphere, huge windows with beautiful views of the bay. The service was great, waiters were very attentive and helpful. Drinks were good and came out quick and to top it off the food was great. I had the clam chowder for a starter, crab enchiladas for entree, and chocolate moose cake for dessert. One word YUM! Definitely will go back. Would like to take my mom there ;)
author: Tea L.

description: I came to the city and once again never been frustrated the way they prepare the yellowtail carpaccio.The roasted crab cooked to perfection no massive oil.The  cioppino full of seafood , price is not an option as the staffs are very attentive and made your stay special and the food is outstanding.The hesitation to give 5 stars is the parking ,it's outrageous I was hoping it should be free not just for 2 hrs of validation but a minimum of 3 hrs so you are not rushing in enjoying the view of the Alcatraz while sipping your hot chocolate or your white wine!
author: Aries G.

description: My first visit to this landmark. Been in business since the 50's, so they must be doing something right. To test the waters, i ordered the fish & chips. Good breading, flaky cod, great fries along with a unique flash fried brocholi side.
author: Ben Y.

description: This is a great place in many ways. There are excellent waitstaff employees and hosts/hostesses. The views from their location are spectacular: Alcatraz, the Golden Gate Bridge, Sausalito, the bay. Wonderful. And best of all, the food is tasty, well prepared and delicious! Love the crab enchiladas. Incredible. The best ever. I would go back just for that dish. Highly recommended. Check it out - even if you live in SF and never go to the Wharf.
author: Mike L.

description:
This is a cool place to go for the first time, but not repeatedly. 

Its a very pricey location, which is fine but not for what I ordered this last time. I got the Halibut seasoned in a mild curry thai broth and it definitely wasn't a 5 or even 4 star meal. 

The view from this restaurant is priceless, I was seated by the window and got a nice view of the Bay.
author: Kayla H.

description: Wonderful location on the wharf with great views from almost every table. We had good service and good food for lunch on a holiday. I thought the Fish 'n Chips was superb. It was served with the most delicious ("flash fried") broccolini. You really have to try it! My dining partner found the clam chowder to be excellent, not too thickened, as is often the case. Not the classiest place on the wharf, this has more of a fifties diner decor, but pleasant and cheery.  We really enjoyed it.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Hubby and I got into town on Tuesday night and was starving. We wanted fresh seafood and decided to try this restaurant since it is in prime location. We called as we were walking over there in case it was busy. We got a busy signal during both times we called. Arrived at restaurant and walked up the stairs to hostess stand. Two girls were there and one led us to our table and took off without a word. I should have known what kind of dinner we were in for. I will break this down into two categories:

Food - we were given a 6 inch loaf of bread with butter to munch on. It was hard and dry. We ordered a small size calamari which was greasy and the squid was not fresh at all. It tasted old. So disappointed. I ordered the seafood linguine which consisted of 2 small crab legs, 1 small crab claw, some clams, squid, 3shrimp in a spicy tomato sauce. The sauce was creamy and sweet which was described as a clam/Worcestershire combo. Every seafood item in the dish was not fresh. You would think that a restaurant that was in prime Fisherman's Wharf would serve fresh seafood. My hubby ordered the spicy shrimp pasta. He did not enjoy his dish either and it had a small quantity of shrimp. Both entrees were small portion for price. He ordered sweet tea and I had water. The water tasted gross and unclean so I squeezed 4 slices of lemon to make it better.  Total price tag was about $78 before tax. Way too expensive for the portion size. 

Service- bad hostess- I see why the phone kept ringing- they were too busy socializing and playing on their smart phones to pick up the phone. Btw, they were not busy- plenty of empty tables. Our waitress was very nice but was not around much at the end of our dinner- we kept having to track her down. We received more attentive service from the guy who was the assistant waiter. 

Location- we were seated next to the serving cart where they placed the prepped bread/butter plates. They also keep silverware and other items there. It was noisy and when they cleared tables, we could hear the banging noises behind us.

Overall summary- bland food, not fresh seafood, slow meh service, expensive.  I would never come here again. Please be aware that this place did not serve fresh seafood during our dining experience.
author: C C.

description: Cool view, friendly staff, but food was not good. Concierge recommended it, but we were really disappointed.
author: Amy R.

description:
My husband and I went to The Franciscan on our CA vacation and our meal was amazing. I got the boneless short rib and it was tender perfection. We also had the crab chowder which was amazing! 
Highly recommend!!
author: Christina M.

description:
We walked in for dinner around 7:20pm on Friday August 29th. I was prepared to have a decent wait to get a table; instead our party of four was seated immediatly. We were greeted by a very friendly hostess who seated us in a booth with a view of Alcatraz. I felt bad for our poor waiter who kept trying to welcome us to the restaurant and start us off with drinks; he was very polite and apologized for interrupting conversation (I was reuniting with my college roommate who was visiting from out of town and I had not seen her for 9 years). Eventually after checking on us about three time we decided on what we wanted to order. Our waiter also was able to have great conversation with us when we allowed him too lol. The four of us each ordered the 3 course meal for $30 a person. 
I had the house salad with a vinaigrette dressing. I usually am a honey mustard girl but sadly they did not have that dressing. The salad had tomatoes, sun flower seeds, onions, and avocado. Followed by the crab enchilada which was beyond amazing! Lastly we had the frozen custard. The "custard" was good but I think it needs to be renamed. I had expected a custard like texture but instead I really felt it was a cup of vanilla ice cream that had melted half way. 
All the dishes had been presented in the appropriate type of plating except for the custard. I was disappointed to see it served in a glass tumbler cup. 
All in all we had a wonderful dinner and meet up.
author: Kristen B.

description: Yummy!  My bf and I come here ALL the time.  We get the Too Two crab and it is soo good! The Crab tastes fresh and is very plump! No skimpy crab legs here!  I would say it is much better than Crab House even tho it's the same company.  The crab tastes fresher and is not as oily.  Also they cut it up for you which is nice since it comes out so hot.  Food comes out quick too! We tried the chocolate and banana sundaes and they were very delicious and light.  I would come here every week if I could!
author: Lora L.

description:
we had a wonderful meal on NY day in The Franciscan.    Everything was excellent.  
Especially the company.    We got the combo fish platter and couldn't have been happier . . that and a beer !     Our server did an excellent job!    The view can't be beat.     They validated our parking too.
author: Jean H.

description:
I came here with my sister the second day she was staying here.  She had received some gift certificates that were good here and we decided to come here for a light lunch.

We enjoyed the decor which I can only qualify as well maintained 50s style with pictures of old actors and famous patrons adorning the walls.  The view was quite nice so we were hopeful after the great lunch we had the day before at Castinolas although the feel of the place seemed a bit cold and uninviting to me.

They brought us bread and butter and I was surprised at how good and fresh the bread was.  There had been comments in some of the other reviews about how hard the bread was but this style of bread is made to be crusty and was well executed.  I had similar fresh baked bread in New York and Costa Rica and this reminded my sister of the bread she would get in France when she lived in Lille.

We both ordered the crab sandwich with fries and an inexpensive bottle of wine to split between us to keep the theme and price similar to the meal we had the day before.  The crab was sweet and fresh, but the bread was reminiscent of the cheap store brand sesame egg hamburger buns you get at Safeway when they've been sitting around for a few days.  I didn't hate the sandwich but I didn't enjoy it, especially for around $15 each when I knew for the price of this sandwich I could get the ingredients and make four of these bad boys and have it come out 100 times better.  The french fries were pretty good but not as good as I had the day before.

The wine we got was okay.  I wish we had sprung for the Chardonnay instead of the wine we got which was a bit too sweet for our meal but we wanted to keep things about the same price for comparison. With tip the meal we had was a little over $60 for the two of us, almost exactly the same as our meal the day before at Castinolas only this meal was just okay and we didn't get dessert.  

There is a good chance that if we had spent $60 each instead of $30 each we would have had a much better experience but even if that is the case I think it is sad when a restaurant doesn't take the same care and pride in planning and preparing all of their offerings.

I would not return here for lunch.  If this place serves mediocre to good food I would likely only come here in the right company for drinks, appetizers, and bread.  I could be convinced to try some of their more popular dishes provided the drinks are strong enough to loosen the grip on my wallet or someone else was paying and it wouldn't be my first choice by far.

Meh. I've experienced better.
author: Theron L.

description:
I came here with the parents for mother's day and we had an early dinner. The restaurant itself was very nice. Lots of pics of old hollywood movie stars, and the interior design was very well done. 

Here's what got me...the menu. Seriously, this was the coolest menu ever. It's basically a cook book! It has a table of contents at the front, and you flip through and check out the different sections, while looking at the photos of the food, along with a description of how to prepare it. I thought that was so neat, I had never seen that before. 

Slightly over-priced, but not terrible considering you're at a fancy restaurant in a touristy/famous area. Very classy. Creative menu. Outstanding service. Great views. Decent food.
author: Julie F.

description: First time here. Probably the last. Had the half fishwich for $6.99. Fries would have cost $3.99 more. I don't think so. The half fishwich was a very nice portion actually, but why would you serve a hot sandwich with a really cold bun? Anyway, the fried fish was served with a delicious coleslaw that tasted like kimchi to me. It worked! Nice seating area with outside tables and benches available. Grumpy order-taker.
author: Reynolds L.

description: Not just for tourists for sure. We live in the city and have been to The Franciscan several times. We enjoy it. The view is special and we had a window side table with binoculars there. A nice touch. We always order the crab fondue- it's special - tons of crab in it and you need the french bread as well as the provided bread to eat it all. My wife had the short ribs which were perfectly cooked, melted in your mouth. The Basa was very tasty and sauced extremely well. I had the $29.95 dinner that included a salad, basa, and dessert. Wine list is extensive but I just had the house cabernet. Very friendly service.
author: Michael D.

description:
DO NOT waste time or money eating here.  IF you must take in a view at the wharf just have a drink, as the only redeeming quality is the view!

The food is expensive and not that great, Boudin will make your wallet feel better.   Since this place is a tourist trap, listen to the local point of view when looking for seafood in SF. 

You want good crab?  Go to "Art's Crab Shak" in Oakland, no view but it's an institution, the crab is "le bomb" and not a waste of money like all places at the wharf, trust the locals... 

Against my will, a friend from Socal was visiting and expressed she wanted seafood and to eat at the wharf, yes i tried to talk her out of it.  But i could see she had her heart set on it.  I chose this place not actually having dined here before.  Listen to the little voice inside you.

Mediocre food aside, a very inebriated couple sat behind us.  The restaurant was nearly vacant, it was  sunday night at 6pm....  They ordered the bar and a HUGE platter of crab legs which they devoured like Orcs.

At one point they began to argue, the man stood up and shouted at the woman and lifted the platter of crab and threw it at her face.  Crab was everywhere and the folks around them FRIGHTENED, as the man could barely stand and clearly wasn't finished, he had a glass in his hand and was very angry with the woman, lady, hired ho, or whatever she was.

Glass and grab were everywhere, not to mention the entire contents of their table on the floor and glass broken.  the man, walked out and left her there.  as the #2 best little drinker in the world, the woman sat there and didn't seem phased by what happened, just looked down at herself and muttered "someone needs to teach that man how to act in public"...looked at our table and noticed the crab that had splattered ALL over my new coat and said nothing before getting up and walking out, with a giant crab leg sticking out of the back of her pants, that got me through the whole experience, hysterical!  I overcome obstacles, someone give me a medal!

the staff needed an enema to clean up the mess. 

i wanted to die, then stab the man, but he was very angry and after that outburst, i wasn't going to ask for trouble.

the manager came over and apologized, but not before outing himself.  he admitted they looked like trouble when they arrived and how drunk they were.  THEN WHY DIDN'T HE PUT THEM IN A CORNER????

Gave me his business card and told me to send the dry cleaning bill and they would compensate me.  Which i did and i never received a response or reimbursement.  I've called and sent three letters to no avail.

Although this was not the establishments fault, they should have been more thoughtful about where to seat "problematic customers".  Good customer service would be to respond and at least offer to comp a portion of our meal, at the least delivered on their promise for the dry cleaning expense.  

btw, i had a glass of wine, 1 appetizer and coffee, hooters would have satisfied me much more, and that cost me nearly $45 bucks OUCH!

BAD PR, BAD FOOD, BAD MANAGEMENT, BAD CUSTOMER SERVICE, BAD IDEA!!!

Please don't make the same mistake i did.
author: erica u.

description:
Stopped by here for snacks and drinks after a couple of hours of urban hiking.  Reason why I chose this place among the hundreds of other seafood places on the Wharf?  The location and huge windows definitely guarantees a great view no matter where you sit.  We hung out at the bar and had great views of Alcatraz and the GGB.  

Drinks were fine.
Food was good. I had a half-dozen of the Hog Island oysters; definitely fresh and chilled perfectly.  A friend enjoyed the crab chowder.
Service was good; nice bartender and friendly wait staff.
The place seemed well kept: clean tables, clean floors, etc.  

It was a nice getaway from the craziness of the Fisherman's Wharf area; will definitely visit again.
author: Angie M.

description: I always go here for a romantic evening., but be expecting to spend at least 200 dollars or more for two people.  It's a very nice place to attend also has great customer service.  Pretty classy and awesome food...the best days to go are on Friday nights and saturdays.  Also, the parking is validated directly across from the restaurant.  I always feel welcomed to come bak to this place.
author: Karissa B.

description: I love the retro feel of this place. Newly redone. The fish is fresh and I love their frozen custard. I've been there half a dozen times and I'd say service can be FANTASTIC or OK but never bad. It just depends on what waiter you get. It's the IT place to take out of town guests and give them a WOW San Francisco feel. DO have the crab avo appetizer, crab fettuccine, and brownie Sunday, they are the best. The crab chowder needs a little work because its not made with the shells for a good crabby tasty but with a roux and tastes a little fishy. But the other dishes I mentioned are FANTABULOUS.
author: Kitten M.

description: I had Pacific oysters and dungeness crabs.  It was delicious.  That was a lot of memorabilia throughout the restaurant.  The view was impressive.  You could see Alcatraz.
author: Eliot P.

description: Loved the hot sizzling crab on the skillet, didnt love the bartenders skills, or the not so friendly staff. A great wharf seafood restaurant, if you are in the area.
author: Lisa S.

description: Nice place with a great view. The oysters were delicious, and the crab was sooo good. Prices are not to bad considering the location and food. We liked it and will go back next time in San Fran!
author: Kyrene G.

description: It's a tourist place.  Love the roasted mussels.  Oysters were not that great.  The food definitely delicious.  However, so is the price.  Very pricy.  Service was good.  So I give 3 1/2 Stars.  4 stars for service, 3 stars for the price.
author: Lisa C.

description:
What a tremendous dissapointment! But.... I A-OK the crab chowder, the roasted whole crab, and the amazing view.

The Franciscan is a lively restaurant that is truly unique but not so exciting.
author: Thyrone A.

description: Totally awesome service! We tried a little bit of everything. Mussels and clam chowder are so good. Others are just ok.
author: Jiayu Q.

description:
I like this restaurant for when I bring guests down to Fisherman's Wharf.  All the restaurants are overpriced in that area but at least with the price you always get wonderful service, validated parking and the food is good.  They also have the coolest fish silverware!  The best time to dine here is before sunset so you can take in the view.  

I tried the pre fix menu on my last visit and thought it was a great value for all that you get.  I had a cup of clam chowder, crab enchiladas and ice cream for $24.95.  I don't think I would get the crab enchiladas again though because they were so rich.  I think I will stick with the crab legs which is what I usually order.
author: Holly R.

description: I took my wife there for our anniversary. We felt like we were dining at a fancy joint in the 1950's. The entire restaurant screams style from the architecture, to the decor, to the staff's uniforms. I was delighted with my order of the black linguini with clams. Very plentiful portions for the price, and loaded with flavor. The service was outstanding, which is quite unusual for this type of restaurant, but was quite welcomed. Highly recommended for a special date.
author: Sean S.

description:
Reasons why this is a good place for family gatherings:

1) They are open on major holidays such as Christmas.
2) The views are lovely.
3) The food, while not particularly good, is not completely vile.
4) The service, while not particularly good, is not completely atrocious.
5) The cocktails are VERY STRONG and served in PINT glasses.
author: Tsada K.

description:
I'm really surprised by some of these very negative reviews, but maybe they are just out of date, given the fact that The Franciscan just underwent a large remodel.

Given that the restaurant is smack dab in Fisherman's Wharf, you're certainly going to get a touristy clientele. But don't let that dissuade you, since you'll be missing out on a great view, old yet updated San Francisco charm, and surprisingly tasty food.

Parking is a cinch - they validate for up to 3 hours for nearby restaurants, and walking up to the restaurant is impressive enough - there is a sense of history here, neon sign and all. It's a large space inside, bustling when we went in on a Sunday evening. If you can, request one of the curved booths, great for four people, yet intimate enough for two.

Food options are decided seafood-oriented, but there are some hearty beef options as well. This is not a place for vegetarians, nor does it need to try to be.

We started with the burrata, a house-made creamy mozzarella, drizzled in olive oil, that was literally like a spread it was so soft. A nice complement is an assortment of meats: prosciutto, coppa, mortadella, salame, all imported from Italy no less. You can choose all four, which is what we did.

For a middle course, we went with the crab & smoked salmon crostinis, which were a nice spin on a regular appetizer. For entrees, you can order all kinds of fresh fish and pair it with a favorite sauce or cooking style, and the servings are large. We actually opted to go with the iron skillet roasted mussels & crab, which honestly I don't remember having crab more delicious. Piping hot, seasoned just right, and with a bib to catch any of the excess glorious mess, we were in seafood heaven. 

Our waiter Tom was great as well, very friendly, checking in on us at just the right occasions, and that only added to the experience. We also tried a few different glasses of wine with each course, and these also complimented the varied dishes quite nicely (Tom was there to offer suggestions as well).

For dessert, and trust me you want to leave room somehow, make sure you to get their fresh made frozen "kustard" which is simply outstanding. Reminded me of Coney Island or something.

For a special occasion, or when the parents are in town, I'll be sure to return to the Franciscan. It's definitely a little pricey, but as with many good things in life, it's worth it.
author: Nish N.

description:
Here's what gets the Franciscan a star: good view of the Bay.  And you need a good view of the Bay, because if you make eye contact with your food, you're going to throw up in your mouth a little.  And no one wants that.

It is no surprise that the Franciscan is located deep in the heart of the Tourist District.  I'm sure that the fine folks from Oklahoma City and Des Moines just love the cuisine, since it's very similar to what they eat at Long John Silver's, Appleby's, and any restaurant whose subtitle is "A Family Restaurant."  If you put this restaurant on Valencia, in the Castro, or in Noe Valley, it would be closed in less than a month.  My only regret is that when the tourists go back to Ypsilanti, they will talk to their friends about how they "ate in a real San Francisco restaurant" and will be taking about the Franciscan.  I shudder just thinking about it.

One more good point about this restaurant: you'll get absolutely awful food, but you will get an amazing quantity of it.  One of my fellow diners got the fish stew, which I think was served in a 3-gallon toureen.  Upside: your dog will have a lot to eat.  Downside: he'll hate you for feeding him this.  Even dogs have standards.

If you find yourself in the neighborhood of the Franciscan and an international terrorist forces you to eat food in 10 minutes or he'll nuke Greenland, either buy a chili bowl at Boudin's or eat your own left arm.  But don't go to the Franciscan.
author: Ben P.

description:
this place is gorgeous and has a great view. But the food, on the other hand, was a big disappointment. first of all, it's a huge place and their menu is literally like a catalog. Pictures of every single thing, as well as step by step directions on how to make it. that was kinda cool.
However. For a fish place with such an extensive menu, you'd think they'd at least have some scallops and lobster. Nope. Just crab, shrimp and muscles. Besides the usual fish selection like tilapia, salmon, and trout, etc.
the calamari was pretty good, and so was the butter lettuce salad.
the clam chowder was not too impressive. too much potato that was clearly just added to make it ridiculously thick. and the crab was tiny! and they i had to ask for the shell cracker/seafood fork/bib.
i was pretty disappointed. a $50 meal shouldn't be disappointing. Especially at the Warf.
Oh well. Ah, and don't forget later when i ordered the jasmine-orange tea that they brought me hot water and a glass. they forgot my tea. and by the time i got my tea, my hot water was just warm. haha. how can you screw up tea!!? oy vey.
at least our waitress was nice.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Pros:
   Great Seafood (Crab, Cocktails, Clams)
   Full Bar
   Nice View and Location
   Cool Decor
   Newly renovated
   Friendly service
Cons:
   Parking
   A bit touristy but all good fun
author: Tom W.

description: Pretty touristy and the food is not anything to write home about (not much to Yelp about, either).  View is nice overlooking the harbor but at night that's not saying much.  If you only have a couple of nights in the city I would skip this place.  Maybe oysters for lunch.....
author: K E.

description:
Why?  Why did I come here?  Was it because I was coerced by insane coworkers?  Oh yeah, that's why.

Food was poor.  Dickensian poor.  Bordering awful.  I felt bad for our server, who was actually very nice.  The place itself looks like it hasn't been updated since 1964.  Could be very cool, but it's a little weathered and shabby.  There was a discarded, half-empty glass of some beverage left on the window sill at our table.  What is this, a frat party?
author: Freccia S.

description:
Great view of the bay. The waiter was nice but not as helpful as you would expect. Led us to our table, took our order and brought our check. Never checked on us. The water boy was a lot more helpful. 

I ordered the clam chowder in the breadbowl. Couldn't taste the difference between a $2 can of Cambells Chunky clam chowder. My husband ordered the chicken asparagus pasta. Ok. Colorful but bland and the olives overwhelmed the dish. Overall, nothing great and overpriced for what you get.
author: Jeri B.

description:
I don't think the locals like this place - too touristy, too much front and center on the Wharf, too many ritzy pictures of hackneyed never-weres as you go up the stairs.

Me and The Honey loved it and here's why:

1. A couple of large cocktails.
2. One bottle of Cakebread Chardonnay.
3. One massive platter of Dungeness Crabs.

It's really not that complicated.

That all adds up to a spendid lunch - add in the gorgeous room, art deco building and the view over the bay, finish off with a double espresso to steel us for the adventures of the rest of the afternoon.

This is what weekends away were made for.
author: Paul M.

description:
I had always written this place off as a tourist trap...good to take out-of-towners for the view and the crab, but not a place I'd think of to go otherwise.  After trying out the food, I realize I was wrong.  We had a really tasty fresh mozzarella and sliced Italian meat appetizer, which was stellar.  The cheese literally melted in your mouth and the meat was thinly sliced, beautifully arranged and a tasty compliment to the cheese.

The crab was the freshest I'd had in Fisherman's Wharf.  We tried two versions, a crab and salmon crostata to dream about and a roasted crab and mussels skillet.  Both were delicious, but for different reasons....the crostata more sophisticated and complicated and the skillet, simple, earthy and just salty enough.

Even though I was stuffed, we had the house-made frozen custard (I can't spell it with a K, sorry) for dessert and I couldn't stop eating it until it was finished.  

Our waiter managed to be cool, funny and informative, without being annoying and intrusive.

One point off for the restroom, looks like the left it off the remodel schedule.  And it's odd that if the Men's room door opens while you are walking to the Ladies room, you get a view of guys standing at the urinal.  Perhaps a partition would be a good idea?!?
author: Kristen N.

description: HATED IT!!!! Ate here with my fam around 9pm. Its kinda pricey. I ordered clam chowder on a bread bowl... it suckd a$$!!!! It tasted like it was jus sitting there all day since the morning... the bread wasnt even fresh.. u can tell the bread has been sittn there and jus been aired out too long. I guess ur spose to order crab since its a crab restaurant, but i wasnt tryna get messy. I will never go to this spot eva again!!!! NO NO NO!
author: Garnette M.

description: taste good with good view and service。oyster is so fresh and clam tastes so good。excellent atmosphere in fisherman's wharf。
author: Xiangru S.

description: Technically I would give this restaurant 3 1/2 stars. Although they have a great view and very good service, their menu is very simple and the food is really expensive for what you are given. The food was good, but I would suggest that you are paying more for the view.
author: Sharon A.

description: Been quite a few times, and been very satisfied every time. I like the vibe and the views! Service is great and friendly. And food is good. It is on Fisherman's Wharf so it has a bit more of a touristy-vibe and the prices might be a little high (I'm from Honolulu so it seems just right to me!) But overall an excellent choice for dinner or late lunch because it doesn't disappoint. Recommend the sizzling platters of mussels, crab or shrimp. Tasty chowder too. I daresay this is my fave spot on the Wharf!
author: Elizabeth S.

description: You are frankly paying for the view, which is a simply amazing view of Alcatraz on a clear late afternoon.  Food was OK with a gigantic tourist-friendly menu as you would expect.
author: Angela L.

description: great food. great views of the bay. their $24.95 price fix menu is a great deal. the place is a little pricey but so is every other restaurant at fishermans wharf. u get good food for the money though. you are paying for a little bit of their overhead as well because of their location. i would give 5 stars but sticking with 4 because finding parking on a weekend is a pain in the ass.
author: Vince N.

description:
This place rocks!  There were 6 in our party and we ate a late lunch/early dinner here last week after a tour of Alcatraz Island.  I have eaten at Scolmas and the Farallon and would actually rate this place higher than both.  Granted that the Farallon is more romantic but the service, the food quality, and the view at this place were 6 stars out of 5.  They make the bread downstairs and I would buy a loaf to take to go with you.  

I am highly impressed and will be back here very soon!
author: David C.

description: OVERPRICED TOURIST TRAP with decent food.  Definitely try the steamed clams and misto sampler.
author: C S.

description:
Location? Check.
Nice view? Check.
Good service? Check.
Food? Ugh....
Clam chowder in a bread bowl - decent
Chicken Arugula salad - too creamy, bland, boring
Chicken asparagus - bland & boring
Fish & chips - decent

Bottom line - zzZZ...snooze fest. There are better restaurants on the pier.
author: Cheryl P.

description: Sad sad sad... Its sister restaurant, the Crab House at Pier 39 is one of my favorite restaurants and since we couldn't get reservations there, we stopped by Franciscan. The garlic roasted crab came out cold on the inside, calamari was severely under seasoned, someone didn't cook the flour out of the roux with the clam chowder, it tasted thickly of flour. UGH! Appetizers were sub par, service was horrible, we had to remind them to refill our water probably 3 or 4 times. No apologies prevailed when we had to send back the cold crab.
author: Vicky L.

description: Quaint and proper, a very nice crab house on the pier. The food here was excellent, I loved the crab feast, which was incredibly filling for the size of crab we ordered. The meat inside the crab was wonderfully cooked and tasted like lobster! If you like lobster you will love the Dungeness crab they serve!
author: Ravi A.

description: Been here many times and still deserves 5 stars. The service has always been exceptional. They are a little slow, but that only allows you time to enjoy the food and the view. Awesome crab, and honestly, just about anything else we have ever tried . Great place!
author: Tim M.

description: This place is great. The location is prestige, the food presentation and taste is divine, and, we really enjoyed the service we received. Luckily we stumbled upon this restaurant the experience has stuck with us since. We each ordered the whole crab- it comes out sizzling like fajitas, but better- Highly recommended. The place was packed but well worth the wait. The service was nice for a change Reese took great care of us and made sure everything was just as it should be. We will return for more, and if you get the chance, I hope you do the same.
author: Sayama H.

description:
I first came across The Franciscan while on a walk with a good friend of mine last year, when he pointed out the turquoise blue neon lights and the devilish red glow coming from the inside of the dining deck. I remember glancing up at the Chihuly glass pendant lights, the hundreds of black and white celebrity photos from the '50s through the early '80s bedecking the entryway -- and retorting, "WHO WOULD WANT TO EAT THERE?!" I pictured that people who ate there were the sorts whose clothes smelled like mothballs, and didn't care about farting in public anymore.

--- However, I did eat there about a week ago.
The bread (from Boudin Bakery across the way) was deliciously toasted and crisp and crunchy and tangy: classic San Francisco sourdough bread. The butter was a bit cold, like it was literally unwrapped in the kitchen and plopped onto a ceramic dish. They were placed on a wire dish rack which was a terrible idea as the bread dish was leaf-shaped, and the rack was clearly designed for round dishes. We nearly broke the dish while tearing off hunks of bread (while waiting for our orders) and moving the plate around was a bit annoying ... but the views were great, if you could get past all that neon.

Our Octopus Conduti was fine. The seasoned beans were tasty and the sliced octopus tentacles chewy and rubbery, but otherwise fine. Maybe it was the 2-3 cocktails we had while waiting for our bread refills and meal. The actual entrees were decent, though I won't say that it was my favorite clam chowder.

My favorite clam chowder still comes from a can & a can opener.
My favorite breads, though, ... I'm a fan of Boudin.
author: Lisa L.

description: A great casual place to come for a quick bite to eat while exploring the area. The food is delicious and the line goes quickly. I ordered the seafood chowder in a sourdough bread bowl. I recommend you sit outside to see the view, but  hold onto your napkins or they will blow away.
author: Sara W.

description: Good food, good service! Bloody Mary, house salad and clam chowder in a bread bowl was more than enough for lunch. Beautiful views and binoculars at many of the waterfront tables.
author: Julianna B.

description:
Came here one night on a whim with my friend from Europe. He had never eaten crab before because his country is deprived of this glorious seafood, but wanted to get a taste of it. We passed by this lovely restaurant and decided to try it out as the menu looked appealing.

We LOVED the food. We ordered the Lotsa Crab and the black linguine seafood pasta and they were both filling and delicious. The seafood in the pasta tasted fresh and seasoned perfectly and they sure did not skimp on the shrimp, mussells, crab, etc. The crab was outstanding and like the name, it was 'lotsa' crab we almost didn't finish it. Our waiter was very nice and helpful (we drank some good vino that he recommended) and was very attentive. The food is great, staff is great, and if you get a good table, you can enjoy your dinner with an awesome view.
 
I would definitely come here again, but it would have to be for a special occassion as it is on the pricey side.
author: Mia F.

description: Our yearly trip to San Fran, no itinerary  :o  so we were at the wharf and wanted to sit outside, have wine and seafood and enjoy the incredible weather. We saw this restaurant. It is a nice restaurant in appearance, inside smells like a grandma's house though. Look no hate replies please, I love grandmas. We went outside, and they have a great patio, with heaters, AND we discovered the fabulousness that is this restaurant. Here's what I'm surprised at. They are listed as really expensive, and it was expensive, but they have a yummy $19 bottle of house Chardonnay, and their oysters are $2.45 each. That is high. But wait. The next beautiful day we went to Hog Island, which is listed as fabulous and less expensive. Not so! The cheapest bottle of wine they had was twice that and the rest I will leave for a separate review for them. So amazing balcony. I almost want to keep that a secret. Amazing house chard; want to keep that under my hat as well. Great food, great service. I mean great! The only bad experience we had here was two male patrons. They were so shockingly inappropriate about their behavior at strip clubs and how to get ahead in the workplace, I almost fell out of my chair. Wish I could have tossed them over to the gulls. Again no hate replies please. I love seagulls.
author: Nancy P.

description:
Just a check back in, and yes, this place was still as good as our first time almost a year ago.  Stopped in for leisurely drinks and appetizers. My bf and I love sitting at the bar so we proceeded to do so, service was attentive and friendly. Their Syrah by the glass was very good and paired well with our apps.

We ordered the calamari, expecting it not to be as good as the first heavenly time we had it but to our surprise it was just as flavorful, fresh, and perfectly fried.  Also ordered the smoked trout, topped with cherry tomatoes, red onions, capers, olive oil, and served with burrata (like mozzarella) on the side.  We topped it on some bread - soooo tasty and just the right amount.

After a couple more glasses of wine we decided to get some oysters and the chic arugula salad.  Oysters were very fresh, horseradish was nice and strong.  Salad was a good size, not too much flavor but the pairing of ingredients was nicely done.  We were way too stuffed to even think about desserts but once again, Franciscan has vowed itself our favorite spot on the wharf, you just can't beat that view !
author: Kristine T.

description: Walking along the wharf it's hard to surpass this restaurant without wanting to go in; the location being right on the bay, and the smell of crab coming from the entrance (of course that could have just been the whole wharf, but didn't care cause this was a great choice). The retro style of the restaurant is awesome, and the staff is majorly helpful with menu choices and table maintenance. I was very pleased to see the menu was more of a display book, with each menu item shown and greatly described. We had to try the crab chowder, it was pretty good but I would say there are other things on the menu that are worth filling up on. Such as the crab melt with fries, or the crab and shrimp louis salad, both of which were beyond amazing! The sandwich was sinfully delicious, and the salad was beautifully presented. The place is just great, for lunch or dinner...highly recommended!
author: Andrew M.

description: The seafood here is damn good, if you're getting a meat dish, you'll be satisfied but not that special.  I recommend the seafood highly.  They also have this marvelous Pomegranate Mimosa, which is totally refreshing.  Their strawberry cheesecake is totally creative, light and hits the spot for dessert.  Their cappuccino's are yummy as well.  I would totally recommend this place if you're in the wharf, however you can also go to their sister restaraunt at Pier 39, which may be a little more fun.  I really like the classy ambiance of the place, they had binoculars in the windows so that you can look out at the ocean, with a view of alcatraz.  However the view of the poopy seagull parking lot is not that exciting.  The waitress we had was perfect.
author: Ronjini M.

description: The seafood plates here were huge.  We ordered the crab chowder to start. For dinner we ordered grabs and shrimp, which were yummy. However, it's messy. It makes sense that they give you bibs!  The cool part is that the waiter gave my friends and I free cookbooks at the end of dinner.
author: Jenn R.

description:
Yummy yummy in my tummy! Nice views of the pier. 

Loved the Prosciutto appetizer. Thinly sliced! Nice and salty! Perfectly paired with soft mozzerella cheese, sea salt and olive oil. 

I got the Dungeness Crab Melt. I wasn't so sure about crab and melting and cheese in a sandwich.... but you know what? It went so well together....

And eating about 3/4 of the sandwich, I finally realized that the tip of the bread was shaped as fins. OHGOODNESS! I totally missed that the bread was shaped as a fish! 

OoOooo crab and proscuittttoooo...
author: Cheryl P.

description: Wow - lovely marble and chrome art deco decor.  Sparkling clean restaurant.  Every room has a view of Alcatraz and the bay.  Each table comes with a pair of binoculars..  Try the combo skillet - great for sharing with a date.  No vegetarian choices, so please don't  bring your vegetarian friends here!  Service and food were impeccable.  A must-do for San Francisco.  Expect to pay $30-40 per meal.  Each comes with complimentary hot ciabatta and a fat slab of salted butter - the perfect compliment to the gorgeous fresh seafood.
author: Sam M.

description: You can't beat the view...the crab melt...or the kick ass wait staff! It is completely touristy...but has food you can respect:D
author: Ginger R.

description: I was so excited to have a good bowl of chowder.  I have to say the chowder was TERRIBLE!!!  It tasted like left over mashed potatoes with a little clam flavor!  Will NEVER go again.  They have better clam chowder at Penera Bread!!!!  Not a place known for their clam chowder.  Linda Vacaville Ca
author: Linda N.

description:
Sunday lunch with the girl  friends.

GREAT view + beautiful weather = great lunch

Food:
Bread is delicious, crusty on the outside, soft and fluffy on the inside.
Crab chowder: could have been hotter but lots of crab meat, not as creamy and heavy than I expected
Garlic steamed clams for 1: so many clams!  The steaming liquid/"sauce" is really delicious and not too heavy.  It was great for dipping the really toasty piece of accompanying bread.  

Service:
Good, perhaps a tiny bit on the slow side but satisfactory.  Actually, my friend accidentally left her credit card in the restaurant and someone chased us down to give it to her.  how nice!

yes, the prices might be a little high, but the view is beautiful, and food was enjoyable.  If I wanted to impress a visiting friend I would definitely bring him/her here.
author: Naoko M.

description: $$$ pretty good - enjoyed their crab dinner for 4, crab cakes and clam chowder
author: Rodel B.

description:
Eh...definitely have had better.  The best thing about the Franciscan is the view.  It's right in Fisherman's Wharf along the water.  

The food, is typical and not extraordinary as far as seafood goes.  Prices are way overpriced for something you could easily get at one of the cheaper cafes along the wharf, down the street.  

Guess I should have figured as much when we came in on a Friday night and there were a ton of empty tables...ah well...lessons learned!
author: Candice M.

description: Another amazing Fisherman's Wharf restaurant. The views here are my favorite. I had the fresh crab caesar salad  and bowl of clam chowder. Both were amazing and super fresh! The place is a little pricey, but nothing out of the norm for these types of restaurants, the bill for 2 with drinks (alcoholic) was a little over 100. So not too bad. I believe they also have a kids menu so it's great for the family as well.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
Not great.  The clam chowder wasn't tasty, and the crab legs did not taste fresh.  Also, they were not cooked in much sauce.  My husband had the crab enchiladas, and they were DISGUSTING!  I took a bite and had two big crunches of crab shell.  The sauce was gross and flavorless, the tortillas were flour (in enchiladas? Wrong.), there was no seasoning on the crab, the enchiladas had lettuce (never seen that before), and there was mozzarella cheese on the enchiladas, which added no flavor and was weird.  That dish is absolutely horrible. 

The only thing my husband liked was the free ice cream that came at the end of the Prix Fixe-- he said it was marvelous.  I'd recommend you get your crab fix somewhere else.  Further, there are better views elsewhere.   Go to the Crab House at Pier 39 instead-- far better food.
author: Lauren B.

description: We went for my mom's birthday and eventhough they were very busy, the service was really good and the workers all have a good attitude. The food was good too!!
author: Juna C.

description: We decided to try this place based on the shape of the building- unique, quite unique. Once inside the decor and views-fantastic. We ordered the crab as our waiter suggested and it was real good. Also, the fried calamari. It was good, fresh but not fantastic. I ordered fried skate, I think that's what it was, quite tasty. My wife ordered the seafood Chiopino (spelling not sure) and we loved it. The flavor, texture, amount of seafood-an unexpected delight. We could not stop talking about it the rest of the night, but we are unabashed foodies. We tried another place the next night and was disappointed, so we came back here the following night and ordered a large chiopino. Wish this place was in Chicago we'd go all the time. Oh, the bread was really good too!
author: grant s.

description:
Service could use improvement, especially in the department of being attentive. It's never been that great but when I recently revisited the Franciscan, I felt like it had gone further downhill.

I LOVE THE CIOPPINO though. Jesus, do I love it. It might say something about my lack of cioppino experience but I haven't found better in San Francisco. I could eat this stuff all day. Or for ten minutes until my stomach is full. Whichever comes first!

The parking garage in the pack of the lot of Fisherman's Wharf was crazy shady but they validated for, I believe, three hours so it made the experience worth it. Time to go to the Franciscan and have crappy service AND fight the mobs at Ghirardelli! Sweet, dude. Sweet.
author: Jen S.

description: As the song goes, What a difference a day makes. Last week I stopped into the Francisan for lunch and was blown away from the moment I was greeted by the Hostess. She was friendly, fun, but most important professional. She got us a great window table making us feel soo welcome but it didn't stop there. Our waiter began our 4 hour dining experience with tasty cocktails, excellent food, meticulous service adding lite and fun conversation along the way! ...and as the Blue Angels were in sync when they passed the huge floor to ceiling windows it was the icing on the cake. What a great dining experience if not the best I've ever had!
author: Googie G.

description: Food was great, but a little overpriced (especially for visitors from Texas). Views are amazing and great for visitors. Decent Bloody Mary's too.
author: Lizette R.

description: We were looking for a nice for dinner. The was it looks great and very welcoming. We walk in and The hostess just stairs no hi hello nothing. Grabs a few menus and starts walking. We ordered a skillet, salads, clam chowder. $98 Was a lot of money for what we got. Very sad.     The service seemed to be rushing.
author: Raffi K.

description:
In going to Fisherman's Wharf, you run the risk of having to put up with rude tourists, over inflated prices, no parking and/or mediocre food. As a local, if you go to Fisherman's Wharf, the Pier, or Ghirardelli, you know these things and you either choose to go there anyways...or not.

Having said that, we decided to take on the Franciscan despite the questionable meal the man-friend had many years ago. We were seated immediately on a Saturday night. We must have just lucked out because a flood of people came in right after us. 

First, we were impressed with the menus! I'm a visual person and LOVED the fact that they had pictures of everything on the menu. I don't like surprises and as a result, hardly ever deviate from the norm. When I ordered the crab fondue appetizer, I knew exactly what I was getting!

Food: Started with the SPLASH: guava juice+ champagne. I wished there was more guava, but it wasn't terrible. The crab fondue was wonderfully fattening and I felt the hours spent at the gym go right out the door. I had the dungeness crab with the secret garlic sauce, and it was wonderful! My only complaint was that I wish I had gotten the bigger portion. :) We also had the crab enchiladas which I had my doubts about but was surprisingly tasty! We ended with the house made kustard ice cream. A fresh, tasty, reasonably priced meal (considering it's seafood). 

The our server was friendly but overworked. We felt bad for him but he was always tentative, friendly and if I he was in the middle of something when we asked for something, he was honest/polite about it with a, "I'll be right with you"-and he would come right back. Understaffed possibly? Maybe someone called in sick?

When we asked what time they closed the hostess told us that, "it depends". She attributed it to the recession and said that they had been closing at 9pm since its been slow, but will stay open as late as 11pm. Not ideal, but it wouldn't stop us from trying to catch this place.

If you can find parking in the lot in front of the restaurant, they will validate! yay! A great find in what is otherwise a tourist-trap!
author: Shawn S.

description: We enjoyed a non-traditional Thanksgiving lunch here today.  Crab feast with fries and the house salad.  Dessert was a chocolate sundae split four ways.   Everything was excellent.  The atmosphere was nice and the view was phenomenal.  Four thumbs up.
author: Sarah C.

description:
For the KILLER DUNGENESS CRAB alone, this place should get 5 stars! We ordered the LOTSA crab smothered in their secret garlic butter sauce enough for TWO to share. It was a little bit over 3lbs of crab and it was yummy, lick your fingers, mouth watering goodness. It came out on a hot skillet and from the first bite to the very last, it was so good! I would come here again just for the crab! We also had the crab chowder, and that was just MEHHhhh to me. It wasn't anything great or out of the ordinary for what we were charged for it. At 10$ for a teeny, tiny cup, you would expect something better. There was actually quite a bit of crab inside, but it was too salty for me, so I didn't enjoy it as much as I thought I would.

One star off because our server TOM was horrible. He took our drink orders, the bus boy brought our drinks, TOM came back once more to take our food orders and we never heard from him again after that. No drink refills, no asking how our food was, nothing. But you can't win them all. Awesome view of the bay, not too pricey, great place to have a romantic conversation with a date or celebrate a birthday (like we did). =)
author: Lucas N.

description:
So me being the Bay Area native, took a date whose a recent implant to SF to be a tourist for a day and check out things he's previously missed.  So one of those things was to eat seafood on Fisherman's Wharf.  After looking through the strip, Franciscan is always one that I forget about being so far detached.  So we looked at the menu and decided, that shall be the place for today.

We walked up the stairs and it was so fascinating seeing all the black and white photos of celebrities along the walls.  I think I was only about to name MAYBE 1/4 of them.  They sat us promptly and right next to the window for the seaside view!  The cookbook menus were a unique sight for me to see, there was a photo of EVERY FOOD ITEM on the menu.  Visual cues are always helpful.  He ordered a latte and we decided to split a half order of dungeness crab with their proclaimed "secret garlic sauce".  The sourdough bread to start was yummy, not the best, but it did the trick.  But the crab, that was truly divine.  We got to wear the oh so fun plastic bibs, metal claw crackers and mini forks in our hands to attack the awesomeness!  The "secret garlic sauce" was impressive and that 1 1/2 pounds was enough for the two of us to be content.

There was even binoculars bolted on a chain next to the window, so you were able to really look far out into the bay and get a better glimpse of Alcatraz.  That was a clever idea.

Our waiter was very polite, even helped us tie the bibs on and opened out wet-naps.  Or maybe that just made his job easier.  Either way, he was quite courteous.

All in all, it is pricey but that's what you get for atmosphere and location.  But this crab restaurant does have some tasty crab worth buying if you have the money to do so.
author: Lori D.

description: Shared the crab fondue as an appetizer with another.  Small but rich, so we felt full right after.  Entrees came and by the end of the meal we were overstuffed.  So no dessert.  Good food overall, relatively affordable, nice views, solid service.
author: P A.

description:
Of the entire weekend this was my favorite meal.  My gf and I walked the wharf in the evening in search of a place to eat.  We happened on this place and were floored by the menu.  Its a menu...but they give you the recipe's like a cook book.

We had the crab, prawns, and mussels roast with mashed potatoes.  Truly excellent simple meal.  Seafood at its most basic.  I'm not sure how they roasted everything but served with lemon butter it was excellent.

We passed on dessert here and walked to Ghiradelli.

Special note.  When we got there she said it was like a 45 minute wait.  We found a seat in the bar and it was actually way better.  They had these intimate little booths that faced the bay so basically you could eat facing the bay.  Was great.
author: Brian M.

description:
Lets be honest. This is a tourist trap, and we all know it, but want to go here anyway for the heck of it.

My friend TC and I came here after the arcade one day and decided to get some seafood louis' and share a tureen of prawns simmered in tomato broth.

It was really good, the prawns were tender, and the broth well spiced. The  salads though were a little sparse, and could have had more seafood, and lettuce, but hey this is a tourist trap.

We went on a Friday night, and the service was not good. So three stars for the decent to good food. But I enjoyed my buddy's company and enjoyed the funny story he was telling me.
author: Charlene C.

description: This is the cleanest and sharpest looking place on the Wharf, with a fantastic view.  Loud, fun, and good food.  The crab louie was awesome.  The fish n chips were just ok.  The staff were grossly in need of help.  The menu was very extensive.
author: Jeff P.

description: Clam chowder in a bread bowl was a great way to start the evening after a long walk from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Wharf. The whole crab costs $37 and was worth every bit, it takes close to an hour to finish the whole thing and isn't overly filling so it feels like the perfect meal. I also discovered my new favourite beer here, "Alaskan Amber". The seafood fettuccine was loaded with seafood and wasn't just noodles with a shrimp or two. Our server looked like JGL and gave great service. I came to the Wharf craving seafood and left satisfied.
author: Jacob M.

description: We are locals who had friends visiting from Argentina. We had reservations for a busy Saturday night, and were seated at one of the best tables in the house! Service, food, views, pricing (for luxury food in a premium area) were all excellent! Our waiter went the extra mile to make the experience extra wonderful! We will return, for sure, especially when out of town guests need a true San Francisco treat! Thanks, Franciscan, for delivering for our important night!
author: David K.

description: Talk about amazing seafood!! I live in SF and I would go here everyday and act like a tourist just for the view and the food!
author: Elena D.

description:
From the look of the staff, table settings, and attentive service, I would consider this to be a fairly upscale restaurant. Even the prices give the indication that this is better than your local Joe's Crab Shack or Hooters. However, the element of surprise that destroys the atmosphere is how everyone patron is under-dressed. This is due of course to the restaurant's location being centralized within the grand central station of tourist travels. Most have their fanny packs pushed to the side sticking out into the aisle and visor pushed up onto their head. 

Now onto the food. I had the Olive Oil Oven Roasted Tilapia. It was one of the fish options where you can choose a fish and then choose how it's cooked. A little oil soaked for my taste, but I'm a "healthy" eater, so my preference would be to just eat it without any oil... It came with a rosemary accent piece on top and potatoes/olives/asparagus on the side. 

My friends ordered a side dish of asparagus and it was enough for two people to share rather than each person getting a separate side.

The free bread and butter was a little hard and crumbly, but it was a staple sourdough bread. 

Probably won't go back unless more friends come into town who want to real tourist feel, but it's probably one of the best places near pier 39.
author: Matt H.

description:
i have never been inside the restaurant, but it looks like it has a great view...this is a
REVIEW FOR THE OUTDOOR CAFE--

The clam chowder is by far the worst I've ever tasted.  Imagine flour and cream and potatoes and thats it.  mostly flour. oh man.
author: Cathleya G.

description:
My boyfriend & I ate here for New Year's Eve last night. This being NYE and his first time in S.F., we were expecting a wonderful seafood meal but that's not how things turned out. We had made our reservations a month in advance so the wait wasn't bad.

When we were seated it took the waiter at least 10 minutes to check on us for our drinks. Then it was quite awhile until he came to take our order. We ordered the crab & smoked salmon bruschetta ($13) it tasted "ok" but what got me was the dang thing only came with three of them! *lol* After our appetizer, we waited and waited some more..then came our dungeness crab legs & mash potatoes, but the server realized we hadn't received our salads yet and took the crab back into the kitchen to serve us our salads (it tasted fairly bland).

After waiting some more our waiter finally came to check on us and I mentioned that we still had not received our entrees. He apologized and told us it was accidentally given to the wrong table and another was being made for us. This really ticked me off because the whole night the servers kept coming to each table confused as to who ordered what exactly. I also disliked the fact that our waiter barely came to check on us the whole night.

Overall the service was poor and slow (the restaurant wasn't even full) and the food was okay but overpriced in my opinion. I have been to better seafood restaurants that I felt were worth my money.
author: Linndsey A.

description:
Today...I was validated! I brought my mother here after my long day which started at 5:30am. I worked until 3:30 and coached at a local high school after wards until 6. I showed up looking, lets just say, not my finest, HOWEVER...I was treated like the group of well dressed wealthier looking folks to the left of us:/ 

I didn't know who Drew Cronis was when we walked in but by the time we left, my mother and I were raving about how kind and sweet he was. Our meals were SO good...I got the surf and turf!! He came around twice and chatted us up. I told him how I was impressed with how awesome the staff has always been and the food is Delicious!
